Title: Better than 2nd Gen!  ***HERE'S HOW TO HELP WITH PRIVACY CONCERNS***
Body: Sound quality is the best I've heard on a speaker of this size!!!  Definitely worth paying a little extra for this one over the 2nd generation model.  I'm not going to discuss the functionality as there's tons of info already out there.  One important note:  If you set up the Alexa app on your phone, IT WILL IMPORT ALL OF YOUR PHONE CONTACTS. I didn't think I gave it permission to do so but Alexa did indeed import my contacts!  You may have read stories how, WITHOUT YOUR KNOWLEDGE, Alexa can record what's being said in your home and then send it to ANY or ALL of those contacts! Yikes!  And, I won't want any of my kids to accidentally send messages to or call people on my contact list. So, if you want to keep your contacts from Alexa and prevent that from happening here's how I did it:Before installiing the Alexa app on your phone, export your contacts to a file and save it for later. Then, go back to the phone and delete those contacts (don't worry, you'll import them back in later).  Now, install the Alexa app on your phone and go through the set up process. At some point, you'll have the option to allow Alexa to automatically import any additions to your contacts.  Please "disable" that option.  After you're done with the installation, you'll notice there are no contacts in your Alexa app!  Now, you can import your contacts back into your phonebook using the file that you initially created and you're good to go!If you already installed the app but want to delete your contacts from Alexa, it's not too late.  Simply export your phone contacts to a file and save for later.  Then, delete the contacts from your phone.  Now, open the Alexa app and click "Contacts."  On the Contacts page, click on "Import Contacts" and enable it by moving the button to the right side.  This will cause Alexa to replace your existing contacts with the now empty phonebook.  After a few minutes, your Alexa contacts will be gone.  Go back and disable "Import Contacts" to prevent Alexa from importing them in the future.  You can now import the contact file that you created back into your phone.Of course there may be some contacts you do want to use with Alexa.  I simply added them manually by clicking "Add Contact."I hope this info is helpful as I wasn't able to find an easy way to manage Alexa contacts.

Title: Love the Dot and its new look, but the sound is still disappointing
Body: I've been a happy owner of a 2nd generation Echo and three 2nd generation Echo Dots for a year now, and I was glad to add this to the arsenal.  After using it for a few days I am generally pleased with it, but it does have limitations, especially when it comes to sound quality (no surprise there!).  I will start by summarizing what's new about the 3rd Generation Dot, then I'll describe the device in more detail, and finally I'll add some thoughts about how to choose which Echo device may be best for you.The most obvious update to the Dot is the new look: it's as if someone took a 2nd generation Dot, inflated it with an air pump, and wrapped the edge in fabric.  And it's not bad!What's different/updated in the 3rd Generation Dot:1) It is slightly larger than the 2nd generation device, measuring 3.9" wide x 1.7" tall (2nd gen was 3.3" wide x 1.3" tall), and the top and bottom edges are more rounded.  It is also substantially heavier at nearly twice the weight of the 2nd generation model.2) The 2nd generation Dot came in two color options (black and white), each of which had a shiny plastic exterior that I personally thought looked a little cheap.  The 3rd generation Dot has a fabric exterior which gives it a classier appearance, and it's available in three colors: heather grey, sandstone, and charcoal.  The fabric and rounded edges give the 3rd generation Dot a much softer look than its predecessor.4) The 3rd generation Dot has a larger speaker (1.6", versus 1.1" on the 2nd gen), which is paired with a larger driver as well.  I'll talk below about the effect this has on audio quality.5) The placement of the microphones is slightly different: while the 2nd generation had seven small far-field microphones on its top surface; the 3rd generation has four microphones.---------------------------Overall appearance---------------------------I purchased the "sandstone" version. The cloth is a polyester woven fabric made up of lighter and darker shades which gives it more visual interest than if it were just a solid, uniform gray. The neutral color blends in with nearly any decor, and the cloth gives the unit a softer look which is great for areas of your house where you don't want something that screams "I'm a device!"Aside from its larger size and slight convex bulge, the top of the device is nearly identical to that of the 2nd generation Dot: it has four buttons (volume up, volume down, microphone off, and an "action" button) and a multi-colored light ring around the top edge that tells you about the Echo's status.  The side of the device has an input for the power cable and a 3.5-mm output jack.One notable improvement is the shape of the power cable, which sits flatter against the wall than the 2nd generation Dot's cable (see my photo to see them side by side).  This may sound like an insignificant change, but it makes a huge difference if you want to plug the cable into an outlet that is behind a piece of furniture.-------------Setup-------------Setting up the Dot couldn't be easier.  You simply plug in the power cable, then use the Alexa app on your phone to connect the Dot to your WiFi network.  The app leads you through everything, and the whole process takes less than a minute.  Boom.----------------Audio----------------I did a side-by-side audio comparison of the 2nd and 3rd Generation Echo Dots, first with music (orchestral, a jazz combo, and some AC/DC) and then with a few newscasts.  Everything does sound better on the 3rd generation Dot, but to be honest, the sound is still pretty anemic.  Compared with the 2nd generation Dot, the sound is slightly fuller, not as annoyingly tinny, and has a small amount of bass presence (not much, but the 2nd generation had none).  Newscasts and other spoken texts benefit from the fuller sound as well, but the difference is more pronounced with music.  Just for fun, I also compared the 3rd generation Dot with my 2nd generation Echo, and THAT'S where I noticed a big difference.  Yes, the new Dot sounds a bit better than its predecessor, but they both sound weak compared to the full-sized Echo.  (To its credit, Amazon doesn't claim that the Dot has room-filling sound.)I'll be blunt: I really like the Dot, but I don't use it to listen to music.  At all.  With so many other speaker options out there, there's just no reason to use this as your primary music device.-------------------------Voice recognition-------------------------As I mentioned above, the number of microphones on the top surface has dropped from seven to four.  I'm not sure what the rationale for this was, but after testing the Dot's ability to pick up my voice from different distances and angles, I didn't notice a substantial difference in the overall microphone sensitivity compared to the 2nd generation Dot.  Like the other Echo devices, though, it seems to have more difficulty detecting voices that come from below it (which happens if I talk to it while I'm on the floor playing with my daughter).-------------------Functionality-------------------The bottom line is that the overall functionality -- what the 3rd generation Dot "does" -- is nearly identical to that of the previous generations (and of other Echo devices, or at least the ones without screens).  This is largely because the Alexa assistant software on which all Echos operate is run on Amazon's cloud, not your individual device.  This means that as Amazon adds new features and updates to Alexa they automatically become available on all Echo devices.  So, you can use any of them to:- Stream music via WiFi from multiple sources- Control smart home devices with your voice- Make hands-free calls to other Echo devices or phone numbers in North America- Make purchases from your Amazon Prime account- Listen to news feeds, podcasts, etc.- Do anything else in Alexa's ever-growing skill set, such as make shopping lists, set timers/alarms/reminders, play games, tell you your daily schedule, and any other skills Amazon dreams up for Alexa in the future.If you don't want to use the Dot's built-in speaker, you can connect it to your own speakers via Bluetooth or by using the 3.5-mm output jack.One new feature for the 3rd generation Dot is a little puzzling to me: You can pair two Echo Dots in a "stereo mode," giving you essentially left and right speakers.  I tried this briefly and the results were pretty much what I expected: yes, it's stereo, but it's still weak sound!  You can also pair an Echo Sub with the Dots, creating a little 2.1 sound system.  Frankly, I'm not sure why you would do this; if I were setting up for stereo sound, I would want speakers that are designed for decent audio performance, not two Echo Dots.Alexa's skill set is enormous and always growing.  In fact, part of the fun of owning an Echo device is seeing what new skills Amazon comes up with (even if many new skills are just silly or entertaining).  I'll mention two of my favorite skills here: the Flash Briefing and the drop-in feature. The flash briefing is fully customizable daily digest of news and other information which you can hear any time by asking "What's my flash briefing?" There is a huge list of content you can add to your briefing including news updates, weather forecasts, sports and traffic updates, and educational snippets along with many that are just humorous or entertaining. Using the Alexa phone app or your Echo account page you can select exactly what content you want in your briefing and in what order you want to hear it. For example, I configured mine with news feeds from NPR, BBC, and Reuters. I love having an on-demand synopsis of the latest news from my favorite sources.My other favorite feature, "drop in," essentially opens a two-way communication channel between any two Echo devices, sort of like an intercom. Simply ask Alexa to "drop in on [the living room, the kitchen...]" and you are instantly connected. My wife and I use this feature to communicate from opposite ends of the house. You can turn drop-in capability on or off for each of your Echo devices individually, and you can also choose whether each device can drop in with ANY Echo device or only those in your own home.[Note that the drop-in feature is NOT the same thing as Alexa's hands-free calling feature. Hands-free calling allows you to call most phone numbers and Echo devices in the U.S., Mexico, and Canada from your Echo by saying your contact's name or number. Just like with a phone call, the other person must choose to answer your call before you can communicate. By contrast, with the drop-in feature communication is instantly established. For this reason you will probably want to use drop-in only with your closest family and friends, and probably only for certain rooms in your home!]-----------------------------------A few (minor) complaints-----------------------------------Unfortunately this 3rd Generation Dot shares an annoying trait of its predecessors: widely varying volume levels within the daily Flash Briefing. As you listen to the briefing, some components (such as BBC News) come through quietly while others (like Reuters) are much louder.  Not a deal-breaker, but slightly annoying.Also, occasionally when Alexa misunderstands a command, you have to "start over," which can be really irritating.  For example, if Alexa thinks you asked to turn on a light but you really asked something else, she will repeatedly say "In which room?" until you say "Alexa, stop" and then start over.  I'm guessing this type of thing will improve over time as voice recognition software  becomes more advanced.  This is really more of an Alexa issue than a Dot issue, but it drives me nuts at times.Finally, I wish the Alexa phone app was easier to use.  It works, but its organization is not intuitive and it feels rather clunky to navigate.  Again, this is more of an "Alexa" issue than a "Dot" issue, but still... Hopefully Amazon will continue to make improvements to it!--------------A few tips--------------1) The Dot seems to pick up voices best when placed at or below eye level (i.e., roughly the level from which your voice emits). Mine has trouble detecting voices coming from below it, so I don't recommend placing this on a high shelf.2) When you select news feeds for your Flash briefing I recommend picking one U.S. source and one international source (I use NPR and BBC - both are excellent). If you add too many feeds you'll get a lot of overlap and hear the same story several times.3) If you have multiple Echo devices in your home, sometimes speaking to one will cause others to respond as well, especially if they are in close proximity (like in adjacent rooms). One way to prevent this is to change the wake word of one of the devices to "Echo" or "Amazon." The only downside is that you then have to remember which wake word you assigned to each device!------------------------------------------------------------------------Echo Dot vs. Echo vs. Echo Plus: Which one to buy?------------------------------------------------------------------------(Please note that I am only comparing Echo devices that do NOT have screens.)When choosing between the Echo Dot and one of the larger Echo devices, perhaps the most important question to ask is "How much do you plan to LISTEN to the device?"  This question is important because one of the biggest differences between the Echo Dot and the larger Echo devices is sound quality: the 1.6" speaker of the Dot simply cannot match the fullness and heft of the Echo or Echo Plus.  (Remember, they all run on the same Alexa software, which means they all have nearly identical skill sets!)So, if you don't currently own an Echo device, start by thinking carefully about how you plan to use it.  Many Alexa skills fall into one of two broad categories: those that rely heavily on the speaker and those that don't.  For example, features that benefit from good sound quality include playing music/newscasts/podcasts, the drop-in feature, and hands-free calling.  (This is why I chose an Echo Plus for my kitchen - I use it every morning to listen to the news.)  If you plan to use your device largely for these type of features, you would probably appreciate the better sound of the Echo or Echo Plus.On the other hand, if plan to use the Echo mainly for "non-listening" purposes such as voice-controlling your smart home devices, then the sound quality isn't as important and a Dot is probably all you need.  In fact, you could even save some money by purchasing a 2nd generation Dot instead -- especially if it's not going to be in a highly visible location or you don't mind its shiny plastic look.  I have several "single-purpose" Dots in my house in rooms where I want to voice-control one thing, such as a lamp in the room, and 2nd generations Dots are just fine for this -- and now that their price has gone down they are a great value!==========Bottom line==========The Echo Dot is an extraordinarily useful and versatile device -- one that becomes more useful all the time as Alexa's skill set expands.  The 3rd Generation model has a great new look, but despite marginal improvements in the speaker, it's still pretty unsatisfying as a playback device for music or  newscasts.  As long as you are willing to accept its acoustic limitations, the Dot can be a wonderful device to have in your home.  And if you DO want better sound quality for the features you use most often, you can always connect the Dot to your own sound system via Bluetooth or the 3.5-mm audio jack.  Hope this was helpful!

Title: Overall improvement, but lost its flexibility
Body: I have 5 Echo Dots (gen 2) and we use them throughout the house for just about everything, being we have a fairly smart home. What I liked about the gen 2 versions, were that they were compact and very flexible on how you could use them. They were easy to mount in different positions and being that they used a fairly standard USB interface for the power, you could really be flexible on how and where you mounted them. The one thing that they really missed on? The well known sound quality.Enter the Gen 3...I really like the improvement in sound. Sure it is not a high quality speaker system, but for the size it is pretty good. Especially when you consider that you can pair them and add a sub for pretty good sound. The look is improved over the gen 2, however it does lose a little bit of the customability that the gen 2 had. With the gen 2, you could purchase different wraps, stands, clock mounts, wall mounts, etc. You could really customize it. The gen 3 is a bit bigger and has a much more rounded shape. While it makes it look better by itself, it lacks the ability to really customize it. It surely would not work as a power socket mount, like you could do with the gen 2, just due to the additional weight.That is before you get to the horrendous power cord and adapter. The power adapter is twice as big as the gen 2 and the power cord went away from the, easy to find, usb style cord to a old style input style and it is permanently attached to the power adapter. This is really my biggest complaint as it took away so much flexibility, that you could enjoy with the gen 2. Don't get me wrong, I am sure there will be several new cords and adapters put out to fill the gap, but that is not as easy as using cords many already have. Just makes no sense. Not to mention the cord is really long, so in areas where you want it to be a bit more discreet, this thing sticks out like a sore thumb.What I like...Sound Quality is a step upSound Volume is much improvedBase look is much improvedWhat I dislike...Much less flexibility on how it is used versus previous versionNon-standard power cordBulky adapterUgly long cord

Title: Distorted trebles (highs)!!!
Body: When playing music, sometimes the sound seems distorted specially the highs (trebles).  If it happens i have to tell alexa to change music. But after several minutes it will be distorted again.I just got it yesterday, I will observe it if it still does that I may have to return  it. I_ very disappointed.

Title: Much better audio quality!
Body: This version of the dot is the first one I would recommend to someone who is interested in a smart speaker but not willing to spend much. The biggest drawback to the previous generation was the sound quality/loudness. I use my echoes mostly for controlling connected devices and listening to podcasts, so I felt like the older echo dot was OK for most things I would require. But even for casual music listening, it wasn't up to snuff. The new one actually has bass and sounds good to me, but it's not going to sound like a Sonos or anything and I'm not an audiophile but I do think this will satisfy the majority of people's expectations for $50. I also have the $100 full size Echo from 2017 and the new echo dot has about 65% of the sound quality and loudness of that model vs the older dot having about 15% of the sound quality of the full size echo. I have been using this new dot for a few days without any issues. I love it and I think you should get one!

Title: Great improvements
Body: The unit is a little bigger than before amazing sound and I like the new look. Power wise you don_ have the USB option anymore just regular plug,

Title: My first Echo Dot
Body: I've waited for a smart home speaker for some time because I wasn't sure which one I should get. Since there are a few to consider. I chose the Echo Dot Alexa for a few reasons. It has a ton of support for smart devices and they have many app skills to pick. The sound quality is great! I was really surprised by how much sound comes for this little device. I am hard of hearing and wear hearing aids and I am very pleased with the sound. I am having a great time connecting it to some of my devices like my Xbox One, Bluetooth headsets, and speaker system. I plan on ordering smart plugs to control my lamps and fan for starters and may look into an Alexa controlled smart TV. All I can say is that Amazon has really made a great upgrade to the previous versions. It was part of the reasons why I picked this one. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a small smart speaker with the ability to control devices and a great assistant.

Title: Love it!
Body: Much improvement over the last gen in sound quality. I currently own 5 different echo devices and use the dot for the bathroom but the second gen was a little underwhelming during a shower. But, that is no longer an issue. Now if we can just get some decent 3rd party wall or socket mounts for this thing and I'll be set.

Title: It's hard to imagine better...
Body: This is my first experience with an Alexa-enabled internet connected device.  I love it.  I no longer understand why anyone would spend more than twice as much on an internet-connected radio when you can get this small package with similar connectivity and surprisingly good sound quality.I had an internet radio, which I really liked, but it was three times the price and had less functionality.  For listening to the news or even music at a regular volume in a regular-sized room, this does more, costs less, and is sleek and relatively good looking.As others have mentioned it could (and probably will at some point) come in a wider variety of colors, but beyond that it's hard to imagine it being better for the size.The one thing that could be annoying is that the lights stay on unless you instruct Alexa not to disturb you.  But then you lose the notifications capability.  For me, that's not an issue, hence the five stars.

Title: Great Sound from a Tiny Speaker With the same options of the first gen.
Body: Loved the fuller sound. The only thing I hated is that the plug it plugs into takes up a whole regular outlet.

Title: Seriously impressive for the size
Body: Get 2!  The stereo pairing is impressive.  I don't have the sub (yet) - but can say the sound quality is really quite good and an immeasurable improvement over the prior Dot's.  If you have your existing dots plugged into external speakers this may not be that big a deal - but if you're using the original Dot standalone - DO NOT HESITATE... No this is not audiophile quality, but seriously impressive for the size.  I would say the sound is equivalent to what the Tap is able to do.

Title: Power Connector is different from Generation 2
Body: Typical Echo Dot. Looks cool and sounds great. Unfortunately this generation 3 uses a different power connector. Prior generations used a Micro USB and I need to use a much shorter power cord connected to a Din Rail power supply. Any idea what voltage and exactly what type of power plug these new devices use?? I can figure it out on my own but if somebody already has this info, you'll save me some research time.  This generation uses a push in round power connector. --Greg--

Title: works great so far
Body: I bought the dot to control a smart light in a bedroom.  I also bought the new echo plus as a hub.  I installed the echo, got the light up and running, and waited for the dot to arrive (I didn't order it soon enough to get it opening day).The dot arrived, I plugged it in, and it was good to go - I didn't have to do anything.  I just asked alexa to turn the light off and off it went.  In the middle of the night I asked alexa to play a prime music "sleep" playlist I like, and it started right up.  I know it can do much more, but those are the two most important things to me and they work great so far.

Title: Slightly louder but not as good as Google Home mini
Body: I was excited when they said it had a better speaker as the echo dot's are disappointingly quiet. Meanwhile the google home mini of the same size is VERY loud and crisp. This new version the 3.0...is somewhere in the middle. A little louder but not quite enough. I was hoping to have one in the kitchen and have it play my audio books while i clean/cook, but its still difficult to hear ti clearly over the kitchen activity. No such problem with the google home mini. Also a downside, they changed the charge port to an old fashioned pin style instead of the micro USB. This limits the places I can use it I have a small powered hub in the living room I connect my devices too and I was going to get another one of these for that, but I won't now since I can't connect it easily where I want to.  I also used to bring one onto the back patio and have it powered by my Anker usb battery, but I can't do that with this one anymore. Not sure why they suddenly abandoned the micro usb style. It can easily meet the 15 watt demand the 3.0 requires.Also if you need/want a wall mount for this version, you can get one to print on thingiverse.UPDATE:Within a few minutes of leaving this review I got multiple calls from Amazon asking me to explain my review....not offering to take it back or to exchange it or solve anything for me...but asking me to explain myself.  The girl by the end of the call seemed nice enough, but the fact that within a few minutes of a review I got multiple calls on my personal cell asking me to "explain myself" seems almost like they're trying to intimidate you away from giving an honest review.  Especially since I think I gave all the relevant details in my review.  Afterwards I was kind of thinking...is this like a modern "mafia thing? Are my orders going to arrived busted up or just go missing now?

Title: Great smart speaker for the price
Body: This thing is awesome. It sounds so good. This is my first device in the echo series and I really like that fact that I can use the app to equalize the sound.

Title: Sound :(
Body: First echo (dot) that I_e owned.. sound started being distorted 2nd day having it. Looked at the reviews and found someone having the exact same issue _hen playing music, sometimes the sound seems distorted specially the highs (trebles). If it happens i have to tell alexa to change music. But after several minutes it will be distorted again.

Title: THE APP YOU NEED IS NOT READILY AVAILABLE.
Body: THE AMAZON DOT APP IS NOT READILY AVAILABLE FROM AMAZON.. YOU WILL HAVE TO SEARCH YOUR WINDOWS 10 SYSTEM OR FIND SOMETHING FOR YOUR MAC.. YOU CAN JOIN AND PAY A WEBSITE THAT MAKES THEIR LIVING SHOWING YOU HOW TO USE THE DOT AND THEY WILL LET YOU DOWNLOAD THE SOFTWARE FOR THE DOT FOR PC OR MAC..  THE APP FOR THIS SHOULD BE ON AMAZON & TAKE ABOUTR 1 MINUTE TO DOWNLOAD AND IN 5 MINUTES OR LESS YOU SHOULD BE UP AND RUNNING.. i WILL NOT JOIN OR PAY A SPECIAL WEBSITE TO GIVE ME THE APP AND SHOW ME HOW TO USE THIS DOT.. THIS SHOUD ALL BE FREE ON AMAZON. I WILL ALSO NOT SPEND 1/2 AN HOUR ON THE PHONE WITH AN AMAZON EXPERT JUST TO DOWNLOAD THE APP AND BE INSTRUCTED ON WHAT TO DO NEXT.. THIS ANOTHER POOR PRODUCT FROM AMAZON THAT IS CONFUSING & FRUSTRATING  FOR THE CONSUMER, BUT MAKES A LOT OF MONEY FOR AMAZON..

Title: Auto dimming feature for light ring?
Body: When I first plugged in this new echo (with the large & rather obtrusive wall plug others have spoken of) I noticed that the light ring on the echo was noticeably dimmer than the previous generation.  After some back & forth with amazon support, they swapped out my unit, and upon connecting the replacement I noticed that the light ring changes its brightness depending on the amount of ambient light present. There is no mention of this feature anywhere, and amazon wouldn_ confirm that it has this feature, but I can plainly see the difference when I turn on or off a desk lamp which shines right over the echo dot.This is a welcome feature improvemnt over the previous generation, as the light ring become less obnoxious at night, but I wish this was a feature I could turn on or off with the app, or had some control over the sensitivity, as it can be hard to see the light ring if it_ dimmed too much.Other than this one issue and the overly large wall adapter, it_ a great upgrade over the previous generation.

Title: Won't Connect to WiFi
Body: Arrived today--have been trying to get it to connect to WiFi ever since. Have spent the last hour trying to contact some sort of customer service. Waste of time and money. Boo.

Title: I'm in love with this little guy!  Unending entertainment and usefulness.
Body: I had no idea I'd love Alexa so much - I wake up in the morning and she does the routine I've set up, and she's so comforting and useful and fun overall.  My husband and I played Skills trivia games for hours last night.  If we had kids it would be even more super useful (kids workouts, stories, games) - we even had a goodnight story read to us by Alexa and it was awesome.  I'm really loving it.  The Echo Dot itself is pretty great - the sound quality is pretty good, the bass when turned up is not that great, but if you really want to rock out you can connect it to other speakers or just use something else instead.  I'm really surprised by how much I like the Alexa app (and the Echo Dot), because I'm a little resistant to technology, but it's pretty easy to figure out and feels like a new little buddy in the home.  I'm excited to get some SmartHome stuff now so I can turn on/off lights, heat, etc.  The only tiny issue I have is that for some reason Alexa doesn't pick up my husband's voice as much as it does mine - maybe because I've used it more?  Really cool, though, overall - I feel like Judy Jetson!

Title: Actually impressed.
Body: I was debating between this and the regular echo. I've had both and we both know what the echo does so all I'll talk about is the sound quality.I'm going to get to the chase. This is the BEST speaker I've ever heard for under $50. The functions of the echo along with the music playing functionality and the sound quality makes it a steal at this price point.The sound is great for its size. It can get pretty loud but the bass is definitely lacking. The bass isn't god awful but it just isn't there.Now I will say this... if your primary motivation for a speaker is to listen to music, go with the echo. If it is but your budget is under $50 then go with the dot. It won't blow anyone away during a get together in your living room but it'll get the job done. The dot will only flourish is an enclosed space. It needs walls nearby to bounce off to cover up the weakness of the bass.If I had to compare the sound to another speaker, I'd say the UE Wonderboom or the older Beats Pill, all of which suffer from weak bass. For the size, I was impressed by the sound but with the Echo at its refurbished price of $69 I'll have to aim towards that direction.I'd recommend this for someone who needs an echo for their kitchen, bedroom or bathroom. It's just not going to hold down a living room unfortunately but overall, I like the sound and if I need a second echo, I'll definitely get a dot.

Title: I wanted to love it, yet the 2nd-gen was better
Body: Unfortunately, I have already put it back in the box. It's too big, the power adapter is huge and covers multiple plugs on a power strip where the 2nd-gen adapter was a normal size. Also, I don't care for the deeper and somewhat 'muffled' sound. It's probably just me, yet the 3rd-gen is huge like a big fat donut, Amazon should just have stuck with the basics for the Dot.

Title: great upgrade
Body: Traded in the first gen dot to this one. Big difference in sound quality. I am using this one in my office where I mostly listen to NPR, Podcasts or Audio books. Good enough to listen to music while working, but probably not for the audiophile. I have a second gen dot as well that I will probably trade in for this one.

Title: Convenient, very effective home assistant.
Body: This is my first Alexa device in an all Apple/Siri household.  We love it. We use it to turn on our GE oven.  Set the Honeywell thermostat.  Make grocery lists with ease.The sound quality is better than expected for everyday use, particularly at only $50.  We like the ease of playing music from Amazon prime.  The downside is a poorly designed power plug which makes me wonder what Amazon engineers were thinking.  This should be redesigned quickly.  It_ way too big.  I_ also like it to work with my IOS Fantastical calendar but that_ a developer issue.  We recommend this product if you don_ mind the oversized plug.

Title: Bad design, IMHO
Body: Very disappointing.  Alexis sounded like she was under a thick blanket.  After talking with customer service, we tried various things which did not help.  They said send it back and they sent another which I received in two days.  It seemed a little better but not much.  I have two 2nd gen echo dots and they are fine.  I found both 3rd gens to have a very muddy bass sound on music and the high end sounds frequently were slightly distorted.  Alexis' voice was so muffled that her voice was unintelligible at times.  I sent the second one back for a refund and bought a second gen echo which is just fine.  I think they got the design wrong on this one.  In trying to make it sound fuller for music, they actually made the sound less clear and sharp.I must add that the customer service experience was a very pleasant one.

Title: Multi-Room Setup Doesn_ Work
Body: I bought this product to set up a multi room music system with my current Echo Dots. Currently, the app is being really buggy and won_ let me set up the multi-room group. Once you select one device, it automatically says the other devices cannot be reached. So annoying! Please fix this bug Amazon.

Title: Stereo pairing isn't the greatest
Body: Just bought 2 of these.  I've had a few 2nd generation Echo dots around my house for a year now.  I was interested in the new dot both for the improved sound as well as the stereo pairing.  The sound is indeed significantly better, perhaps almost rivaling my Google Home.  They are much louder as well.  I would have skipped getting the pair.  Pairing them as a pair was pretty simple.  They will only both play though if you ask them to play something off a service like Amazon Music or Spotify.  I often use one of the sleep sounds Alexa skills at night and figured having a speaker on each side of my bed would create a more enveloping sound.  Unfortunately, it only plays out of 1 speaker.  Also, if I ask it to play a radio station it will play out of both speakers, but when I use it to wake me up in the morning with that same station it only plays out of one. I hear it's kind of the same deal with the sub. I'm tempted to return one of them since the use as a pair is pretty limited.I thought maybe I could just use a few Sonos One, but they can't do timed actions like alarms.Edit:  Impressively, I posted this review in the morning and Amazon called to discuss it with me that afternoon to see what feedback I had on the Dots.  I was pretty impressed that they are that on top of their reviews.

Title: Muffled
Body: I bought this to replace my old Echo Dot gen 2. I am very disappointed. Alexa sounds distant and muffled. Music playback and the alarms sound normal. There is something wrong when she speaks and I have to turn the echo dot up. Only problem is, when the alarm goes off in the mornings it_ super loud. Wish they would add new volume settings is this is going to be the norm going forward. Also, very disappointed in Amazon customer service. I was supposed to have a call back yesterday morning between 8:30am-9:3am CST and it never happened. I will be requesting a replacement device and I_ leaving this bad review in part because of the failed customer service promise.

Title: Alexa
Body: Not sure why i waited so long, this makes turning off lights and fans and TV's a breeze. (smart plugs needed)

Title: Much better sound then the 2nd Gen Dot
Body: Just got my 3rd Gen Dot and this speaker is loud especially if you have the volume turned to max. Alexa's voice is loudest but music can still get loud as well especially if the volume is maxed. Lots of base sound. Great for Ocean and Waterfall recordings. I prefer music not to have to much base so I can turn base off in the equalizer settings via the Alexa App and turn Treble and the other sound setting to max and music sounds much better.I did some testingUltimate Seashore by enviroments sounds good on the Dot 3rd Gen. You can hear each breaker and the very distant foghorn really good.Thomas Dolby's Blinded Me With Science I use this song to test midrange sound and it sounds good on the dot 3rd gen.With this Dot you can hear the music and not require an additional speaker. I will be using this when I'm showering so I can hear the music while the shower is going. If you want though you have the option to add a Bluetooth Speaker or a Wired 35mm Cable Speaker to the Dot 3rd Gen. Amazon has really improved this Echo Dot and it sounds slightly better then the Google Home Mini.I recommend the Dot 3rd Gen and it's really at a good price of $50 if you don't want to spend a lot on an Echo Smart Speaker. It can't compete with the more expensive echo room filling speakers but it's a pretty good speaker for it's size.The Dot 3rd Gen also works with your smart home devices and routines. I tested that as well on my lights. The Dot has 4 microphones and it really can hear you better then the 2nd Generation Dot.I recommend the Dot 3rd Gen.

Title: Great speaker for Music
Body: I liked the speakers improved quality for Music but for the dialogue it was more clear in the older version. My wife did not like it at all. Unfortunately I had to return it with a heavy heart.

Title: Waste of money and time
Body: Biggest piece of garbage amazon has ever sold!!!! Purchased one a week ago and didn_ work, amazon replaced immediately. Same issue will not stay connected to internet. Must be my internet right? Well guess google home and every other product in the house works fine and amazon products (firestick, Alexa, echo) don_ work with Spectrum internet. Will not buy again, will return this one and DO NOT recommend this product at all!,,,

Title: My first Echo.... 2 thumbs up
Body: Without a doubt - it's quite an impressive creature.  It's not pefect...but no tech is perfect... and I love tech.  So...  Amazon added whisper mode today.  Experiencing that today - was one of those very special "wow" moments.... I called my friends to try out that new feature...and they all love it.  It does much more than I expected.  For quite a while I waited, as I thought "I have my iPhone and Siri...why do I need Alexa?"  Well, I love my iPhone... and am still very happy I now have an echo dot.  I don't have any complaints-  just look forward to the continued advancements Amazon's Echo team is making with the device.  The quality of the device is excellent - and the sound it puts out- for its size... really impressive.  Can I live it out it?  Sure.... But is it fun and convenient to have.... absolutely.  Very glad I finally got one!

Title: Echo Dot for Amazon Music
Body: I have been enjoying the Amazon Music BUT the albums and selections I selected on Amazon Music do not always play upon my request and at times some music I do not like starts playing!  Also, the one Echo Dot is all I have and I only want to subscribe to the $3.99/ month option and it will not let me!

Title: Great dot
Body: I like it better than the 2nd gen dot and  echo. Glad I waited for it to be released. Now I need a battery base for it.

Title: Great addition to older Sonos
Body: Quality product. Simple setup with phone app. Decent sound quality but don_ expect much from such a small speaker. Used mine to pair to all Sonos in the house and works great.

Title: The voice response has improved significantly!
Body: So far so good!  The voice recognition is better.  I don_ have to say Alexa multiple times for it to work.  This one hears me everytime, the first time.  The sound is much better so far.

Title: Multi Room Music functionality is completely unreliable.
Body: Multiple chat supports with amazon to figure out why echo dots will randomly stop playing music across the house.  Absolutely no improvement as a result of support.  Apparently this is rare according to chat support; however, plenty of people report the issue.  These devices should be convenient but are extremely frustrating due to randomly stopping.  Sometimes 1 device, sometimes 2.  I ended up returning all 3 after the issue never resolved itself and support wasn't able to suggest a fix or even a reason as to why it was happening.The concept of what these are supposed to be is awesome, but they aren't reliable.  I wish a 1/2 star was possible here.

Title: Solo funciona con energía eléctrica
Body: No funciona bien

Title: Don't waste your money.
Body: Alexa didn't  responded when ask for simple command, even the ones on instruction. I will say Alexa .... the light will come on, in a second it will turn off. or I will give the command super fast before the unit when to sleep mode.. and no respond. very frustrating to deal with this crap. I send it back. if you want to get frustrated, then buy this unit.

Title: Fantastic Upgrade
Body: As a user of the 2nd Gen. Echo Dot, I can tell you that Gen. 3 is the one you want if you don't use an external speaker system. The sound is much sharper and cleaner than previous versions and even music sounds better on it. What I like about the Echo Dot is that you can pair it with another Dot to play music in stereo without the use of Bluetooth or directly connected speakers. A worthy upgrade.

Title: Perfect
Body: I didn't think I would ever get an Alexa, why I live in a tiny house.  But it works great.  I don't leave the TV on IHeart radio on anymore, my light goes on in the loft when I open the door.  And a great alarm wakes me in the morning.  I love this little gadget... Toys for adults... And this one is sweet

Title: Looks and sounds great!
Body: So we have 4 of the second generation dots and was excited to see the new one. Set up was super fast, sound and looks great!  Can_ wait for the Black Friday special where I can add a few more in the house. Want a cool stand?, we used an old bath and body candle stand, works perfect and looks great!

Title: A HUGE improvement in sound quality from previous gen
Body: I had the 2nd gen Dot every since i came out, I never used it to play music, because the speaker quality was just not fit to play music.  Then yesterday I got this new 3d gen Dot, and gosh, not only the sound quality improved, the volume also improved! I got chemical burn on my private part from hair removal cream due to i didn't hear the timer on my 2nd gen dot, but the 3rd gen is so loud that you'll hear it for sure! The speaker quality on the 3rd gen dot is really good, i would even say it is better than my 2nd gen Eco!!! The sound from this 3rd gen Dot is loud, but smooth, unlike the 2nd gen Eco which hurts your ears when playing at loud volume and sounds are all distorted. I would def play music on this 3rd gen Dot from now, cuz it sounds good enough for listening music and won't sounds like if you were listening music on your great grandfather's handheld radio thingy. Oh also the look of this device is much better than the previous one as well. The previous one looks like if it was only $20.... but the look on this one at least $50 lolThe only reason i gave it a 4 star is because when playing music around volume 8-10 it can't hear me calling her name, and i have to scream on the top of my lung( like if someone were to stab me kinda scream) for her to hear me. So now i just walk to her and control her instead of using my voice cuz i'm too weak to scream to her multiple times a day.

Title: It_ not crazy loud, but is perfect for the price.
Body: Perfect helper, speaker, home utility.

Title: new echo added to the family
Body: This is not my first echo dot. I've bought many in the past and enjoy placing them around my home. Don't get me wrong, they're great for simply asking the weather, turning on the thermostat, turning off the lights, or any other features you might find useful. The new and improved speaker is definitely better than that of its predecessor, however, the bass and treble still seem to be off. The app is now more convenient to maneuver and find the controls for your home.I will still continue to setup smart home groups, and use them for multi-room audio. I look forward to receiving my other echo products shortly. Amazon has reinforced their lineup, and I'm proud to be their consumer. I've only had this device for a week, so I'll periodically update on here after I experiment with the device more.

Title: Can't Connect 3rd Generation Dot to my music group
Body: I have 6 Dots, four Echos, two Shows and one Tap. I conduct a lot of training for Occupational Therapist on the benefits of a smart home. I have been able to setup all of my devices (except the Tap for obvious reasons) to be able to play music throughout my home.  All of these were straight forward to connect together. However, I cannot connect the new 3rd generation Dot I got on October 11 (I preordered it when it was announced in September). I don't know what i am doing wrong, but the setup was just like all of the others - same Wi-Fi network and using the new Alexa smart phone interface. This is also the case for my Android and iPads. On top of all of this, the Help selector on the smart phone interface does not work, so it does not give me any assistance. Perhaps this was rushed to market too soon.

Title: My first Dot. I went and got a second one too!
Body: I am making an effort to be more tech savy, so tbh I am easily impressed. But I love my dot. I talk to Alexa all the time. I enjoy having by phone sync so that I can listen to podcasts and music while I'm getting ready. I set alarms for work, add things to my to do and my shopping lists that I can then see in my Alexa Ap. I have Sirius XM and I upgraded my subscription to be able to use it with my dot. I found out a week later that they were having a promotion for a free dot if you upgraded your subscription, so I cashed that in and received a second dot for free! I have one in my living room and one in the bedroom. Everything the dot does is something my phone could do, but I like that I don't have to use my battery and that everything is voice controlled. I was very interested in trying out the google home devices, but now that I have two amazon devices I think I'll just stick with Alexa.

Title: Attractive with great voice
Body: I have a second generation. I'm giving my daughter I had it hooked to an external speaker which work good for that one this one really doesn't need an external speaker it's got great sound I have 2/3 Generations now one of my bedroom one of my office and I have the big echo in my living room echoing all over the place haha the great item I love it going to get one for the car too

Title: Man, does this thing use a lot of bandwidth!
Body: Streaming on any other device slows to a crawl when this item is functioning. I like its responses most of the time. There are times it thinks I asked it to turn off the lights (none are connected) but that might be the way I ask it to perform. I've only tried a few skills and they all seem to have flaws, usually with sound quality. I think overall it's a good product, but the bandwidth issue needs to be fixed.

Title: Great addition for small home office or bedroom etc
Body: So I have never purchased an Echo yet till this point. I am working on my AWS Certified Solutions Architect and got to the point to write programs that will use the Echo. I did not want to spend a lot, but was also hoping to get at least fairly good sound. I had heard the earlier versions of the Dot and was not impressed. But the reviews on this one seem pretty good, so I got it. I can say I am duly impressed. The bass response is a bit lacking, however the sound is clear with a pretty decent frequency response. I work from home and this will definitely sit in my home office for background music. I love that I can easily get things like the current weather and temp just by asking. I am also looking forward to programming some other features to use with the Echo too.I can also see putting this in a bedroom, or a kitchen, or other secondary room in the house. It is more than loud enough to hear while working in the kitchen. And it would give good enough sound to go to sleep by, then wake up and find out the temp outside before even getting out of bed. I am hoping to program it so I can check on school closings at the same time I get the weather in the morning.If you are a very critical audiophile this is not the device for you. But if you just want some good sound akin to a really good clock radio or small portable radio I think you will be more than satisfied.Oh and I LOVE the dad jokes Alexa tells when you ask for a joke!

Title: Quantum Leap in sound over 2nd Generation Dot
Body: Got the new 3rd generation Dot over the weekend to see how it compared with the 2nd generation Dots I already have. I was not disappointed! The sound quality is MUCH improved, sounding closer to an Echo (but without the bass) than its predecessor. I placed it in the kitchen and was pleased with how well I can hear it announce timers and reminders when I_ in the living room. It seamlessly integrated with the other 18 Alexa units we have (2 Shows 6 Echos 3 Spots and 7 Dots) and collaborates in two music groups without any issues. Before, the Dot was a good entry level for just using Alexa, but now with improved sound quality, it contributes to music groups with greater fidelity.

Title: My first Echo device and I love it
Body: This is my first echo purchase and I think I_ hooked. Just moved back from Europe and as I was unpacking it was a pain to stop and change a Sirius station on my phone. Echo dot to the rescue! I had a problem at first setting it up but once I did it_ been amazing. I can switch from listening to Howard on Sirius to asking Alexa to play classical and than to 80_ music. Every morning she tells me a joke and than we start unpacking. I was also very impressed with the sound and how loud she actually plays. Very impressive for such a small speaker

Title: We've been enjoying it!
Body: My husband and I have been having so much with this. Figuring out all the stuff it can do is an adventure. The sound quality isn't great, but we hooked it up to a speaker system and it works very well. The app leave a lot to be desired, I wish it was easier to navigate and had a little more guidance. Switching between user profiles was as easy as telling Alexa to "switch profiles/accounts," but it took us two days to figure that out.. I'm learning that sometimes the most obvious is the way to go.

Title: Works fine -- note equalizer controls
Body: It's louder with better bass response compared with the 2nd generation Dot that I also have. I listen to a lot of speech and that sounded muddy compared to 2nd gen. I learned from technical support that equalizer controls are avialable. They are accessed as follows:1. In the Alexa App, tap on the Devices icon at the bottom-right2.Tap on Echo & Alexa at the top-left corner3. Down below, tap on your Echo Dot4. Down below, tap on "Sounds"5. Then tap on the Equalizer -- here you can adjust the Bass / Mid / TrebleTurning the bass way down and boosting the midrange helped a lot. It sounds more natural and is not as tinny as the 2nd gen model. Speech quality is not great but it's OK. For the price I think the sound quality is fine.One problem I note is that the volume steps when using voice volume control ("Alexa louder," "Alexa softer") are large around my range of interest. It is either too loud or too soft. Using the controls on the Dot I get finer volume control and can get the volume just where I want. I had better voice volume control with the 2nd gen. Dot.

Title: Not worth it
Body: Ok I got this for free for getting a Sirius subscription so I can_ complain about the price. But since I connected it last night, NONE of my Bluetooth devices work now. And I_ not just talking about my home speaker. My headphones and my car no longer work. So I_ really pissed now. This thing has messed everything up and I see absolutely no benefit to it.

Title: Returned 3rd gen for a 2nd gen because they work/sound better
Body: I own a 2nd gen and it works like a dream!! Ordered the 3rd gen hoping it was a upgrade...it's not!!!Pros gen 3:LouderBiggerCons gen 3:Muffled soundCan't hear me in low to moderate noise levelsReaction time lags with wake wordNew plug is not usb compatibleo4 microphones vs 7 on gen 2Long story short..i returned the 3rd gen and ordered a 2nd gen with an indigo case to improve look..never happier!!!

Title: Love my Echo Dots
Body: I highly recommend these Echo Dots.  I have 1 2nd generation and 1 3rd generation.  The sound quality difference is fantastic with the 3rd generation and I have enjoyed going to the learning skills process with great success.I did experience one problem with both Dots today, they both stopped working at the same time.  THat is when I went to my app and saw the notice "Sorry, we are experiencing system issues, Alexa isn't responding as fast as usual.  We are working on fixing this."  So they are johnny on the spot with fixes as well.I have mine plugged into smart plugs  which allows for remote access as well so I can turn on my lights from work instead of having to turn them on before I leave wasting electricity.  You can also schedule your lights, appliances or whatever you plug into the smart plugs.  It's great that the smart plugs come in many different styles and manufacturers as well.  However, be careful as you must have a relatively newer phone in order for your Echo Dot to work with your phone when using some types smart plugs.As I said earlier, I highly recommend the Echo Dot with Alexa it is so versatile, fun as well as a time and money saver.

Title: I like it. Dynamic bass according to volume.
Body: It works great. Much better then the 2nd gen Dot. I really like it playing in conjunction with the 2nd gen Echo. It also picks up my voice a lot better than that Echo, which surprised me. By itself, the Echo sounds much better. I_ actually more curious about the sound of two 3rd gen Dots in stereo with the sub-woofer, then using two Echos with it.I found out you can_ have an Echo and a Dot in stereo. I only wanted to try them like that on opposite sides of a large room to hear the different mixes more isolated, and blending as I move between them. Viva la difference... maybe. Oh well. So much for being a musician and wanting to hear the instruments differently, and more isolated.Actually, what I did right before I got the new Dot, was connect the Echo to a 2.1 sound system and that just sounds awesome. That_ the way to go; I would say, but I still like the Dot and Echo in mono unison as well, depending on the situation obviously.Update:I found the EQ in Sounds setting, so now I like it even more. I_e only heard one album so far, but for now, the EQ settings in the photo really enhanced the sound. The best volume for that is 8, which is pretty loud.Also, I_ sure it needs a more powerful AC adapter than the previous standard USB.

Title: I'd say 2x better than Echo Gen2, and 5x better than Show at understanding us
Body: This little puck does a great job at understanding the whole family, even with pronunciation variances. I own Dot Gen2, Dot Gen3, and Show. Comparing them, I found the Gen3 to be so much better than the Gen2 - a lot fewer "I'm not sure" and "I don't understand". It's also greatly better than the Show (which I now consider to be garbage). I actually bought the Gen3, so I could move the Gen2 from center stage (our Rec Room) to our bedroom, move the Show to center stage, and use the Gen3 in our Living Room. Well, when I made the Show center stage, I soon discovered it's useless, unless you interact with it from 2 feet away (something I didn't realize because it was always on my office desk right in front of me). Long story short, the Gen3 is now my center stage device, and I am now much much happier.

Title: Reminds don't work
Body: Really wanted this to help remind the kids to get things done without me helicoptering over them. The reminders worked the first day and haven't worked since. Reset the device and same thing. Worked for 1 day and then nothing. Got busy tiling my shower, set a reminder for the end of my sons practice and by the time I realized it didn't remind me I was almost 20 minutes late picking him up. This was the feature I wanted most. Disappointing!

Title: A good little speaker and Alex for 50 bucks.
Body: The echo dot has a good speaker on it for 5o bucks. Alexa is fast and understands me perfectly and she fits nicely in with my small bedroom set-up. While Alexa with the Alexa skills app is much smarter than other voice assistants like Siri I dislike how you have to train her. For example: with my Philips hue color lights if I do not use the skills app I must say "turn on Philips hue down light 1". Whereas with Siri I just say "turn on lights and bam!". Not to mention the clunky pairing process of having to jump back and forth between apps. Again with apple and home kit I had to scan ONE qr code and it automatically found all 4 of my lights in less than a minute. Finally, I understand amazon wants you to use their prime music but I do not like the fact that I cannot use Apple Music considering many apple users like myself use this service.All in all a good sounding speaker for 50 bucks, decent intelligence but the clunky set up with the Alexa app and the necessity of the skills app to really make Alexa smart is not very user friendly.

Title: EXCELLENT!!!
Body: I bought this to upgrade from a previous generation of Dot and I'mhappy I did. First, for $50 you get a great smart speaker. I use this in the kitchen because it's small and doesn't take up a lot of space.Secondly, it sounds great. Amazon upgraded the speaker and it's much better than previous versions.Third, great style. Rather than a plastic hockey puck this version has a better cover, feels more solid and has a better design.  All in all, I love the Dot and what it can do.

Title: Steals Contact Information
Body: While setting up Alexa Dot, it asks for contact information sharing to enable calls, etc.  Later you learn that this feature is not available (without perhaps pairing with a phone).  But then there is no way to remove these contacts once you have provided them.  I felt that they deliberately misled me into providing them contacts which is irreversible.  I wish others who go through setup do not make the same mistake I did.

Title: Not a huge improvement, but not bad
Body: I had some issues with crackling and tinny shrieks when I played music, but after messing with the equalizer settings it seemed to stop. I also think it may have just needed to break in, as I_e played music and sleep noise most nights for about a week and the issues are essentially gone. I was hoping for a noticeable sound improvement over the 2nd gen, but it_ essentially the same speaker, just louder. Overall, not much of an improvement or change, but it does look nicer than the older model, and can get much louder if that matters to you.

Title: I can definitely see some improvements over the previous generation
Body: I wouldn't recommend replacing old pucks with these, but they are evolving over the years and getting better and better.  This one went into my daughter's room and is noticeably better sounding than the previous generation dots.  These things are addictive.  They are just so convenient to have scattered around the house.  We're up to 4 dots and 2 of the taller models with impressive sound quality for such a small tower/speaker.  My two oldest gen dots are hooked up to external speaker systems.  The kids are limited to the volume output of the dots :)We find ourselves constantly checking the football kick off times, weather, time, setting timers, or playing music (kidsbop is always child appropriate).  As a note to parents, if you use the old rule of sending your child to a timeout in their room of one minute per year of age, Alexa is super convenient.  The timer is super easy to reset if the child chooses to throw a tantrum midway, heh.  No more forgetting to check the clock and leaving them in time out too long, that always makes you feel guilty.

Title: Garbage
Body: I_e had this item for 8 days and the speaker already sound awful. It has a crackly quality like the speaker is already busted.

Title: Great speakers with a down side
Body: To start off I'm fairly new to the echo world. I absolutely love the product as a whole and capabilities within it.My significant other and I tend to use our echos dot to play music while we work around the house. While the speaker is amazing for the size reactivating echo takes me either yelling over my music or getting within a few inches in order for the wake word to initiate. This is with volume on full blast I haven't tried on a softer volume though.I also originally got 2 of them in hopes to use them as an intercom system, but we live in a house with lots of white noise (aquariums) which the mic being sensitive enough picks up. This might be specific to my use case and the sensitive mic in all other cases is great.

Title: Easy to use
Body: After deciding to buy an Alexa, I researched the different models before selecting this one the current generation.  It is easy to set up and use although it does take a little while to remember what to say when using it.  For example, Alexa turn on the 1st plug and NOT turn on plug 1.  We also have been listening to Amazon music with it.

Title: Nahh
Body: It_ hit or miss, disconnects from WiFi w/o reason, pain in the neck to reconnect.  Don_ waste your time or money.

Title: TREMENDOUS value! Absolutely LOVE my Dot!
Body: I absolutely love it! Bought to use as a radio/ambient noise device as I fall asleep, but now realize the capabilities FAR exceeded what I initially purchased it for, so I also use it as an alarm clock, Bluetooth speaker for my iPad, personal assistant (_lexa, add milk to my shopping list), Amazon Music speaker (which I never used until buying the Dot). The sound quality is really good, especially considering it_ small size and relatively _udget friendly price. I definitely recommend to anyone, and if you_e a Prime member...WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR. Don_ even _dd to cart just click _uy now and watch your life get simpler.

Title: False Promotion Advertising
Body: Love my Echo Dot, had been thinking about purchasing one for a while, but what finally convinced me to purchase it was a notice on the Amazon.com website on the Echo Dot details and purchase page. It said with this purchase you will receive 3 months free membership to Amazon music unlimited. That was the deal maker! It said the promo code for my free membership would be included in the notification email that my item had shipped. Received the notification email but no promo code. Contacted Amazon customer service, was transferred 3 times, to end up back with one of the original reps just to be told this promotion was not available with my purchase & I dont what other bs blah blah blah excuse. Not happy at all...and funny thing is I can't find that promo ad anywhere now. If anyone sees this when purchasing, do yourself a favor and take a screenshot. Hate being petty but hate bs promotion scams more. I was very excited about my free membership!

Title: Great Improvements to the Echo Dot
Body: I'm impressed with the improvements made to this echo dot.  From the simple color options to the more bass in the speaker with a relative clean & simple look.  I have other echo dots throughout my home and made sure that this latest version was in a spot that I use the most.  Happy with my purchase.

Title: Won't connect to WiFi.
Body: The dot I received was defective. After 20 minutes on the phone with Amazon's rep, the unit will not connect to the wifi. Then they expected me to drive to the UPS store and ship it back to get my 99 cents back. Ridiculous, this thing is going in the trash. I'm VERY disappointed with Amazon's poor product and even worse customer service.

Title: Better Sound (than previos Echo Dots)
Body: It seems to have only for mics rather than 6, but seems to work fine with that. I'd estimate that It's about 20% larger and wroth it because of the noticeable improvement in sound quality. I like it.

Title: Finally a woman that can be controlled! (Alexa)
Body: I finally found a woman (Alexa) that listens and can be controlled. (Just kidding) Excellent product. This device saves a lot of time by automating my household items and by adding information and music to areas I spend a lot of time in. Eliminates the need from carrying a radio from room to room.

Title: Mushy Sound
Body: Disappointing.  I thought I'd get better, clearer sound.  It's louder (which I didn't really need) but both speech and music are mushy.  Much easier to understand spoken or sung words with the 2nd Generation.  The extra volume does not compensate for the loss of clarity.

Title: Perfect
Body: No the sound is wrong when I tell it to remind me or set a timer the light goes off but there is no volume and I_e called Amazon twice just to try to repair itUPDATEAs usual Amazon helped me with this one. They have sent me a replacement! Amazon you Rock!! Thank you so much!!

Title: Won't connect to wi-fi
Body: I keep receiving message "No internet connection" when trying to connect the wi-fi even though My  Echo(1st gen) works and this Kindle Fire tablet which I am writing this review. Maybe the "DOT" I received was  defective I don't know

Title: I enjoy this little dot, it makes me laugh.
Body: I live alone and have nobody to talk to. I get a kick out of this Alexa echo dot, she is not real bright at times but she still needs more input. She is like my very own Johnny five. Give her a try, she can be fun.

Title: Alexa's Voice is barely understandble!
Body: This new unit has tried to push a bassier sound more than anything. Alexa used to be crisp and clean - very easy to understand. Now she sounds like she's talking into a carpet and it's extremely hard to hear her. I've tried changing the EQ settings (which are great) but apparently they don't work on Alexa's voice. The response time is also noticeably slower than the second generation.If you already have an Echo Dot (2nd Gen), don't waste your time. If you're looking for better music quality, I would suggest one of the MANY third-party ad-on speakers instead of this 'upgrade'.

Title: This is definitely the best value echo
Body: Were I in product development at Amazon I could see myself actually recommending against releasing this product as it sounds very, very good and will for most buyers make the more expensive Echo irrelevant. For 49.00 - if you want an echo in your home this is the only one you need.It made sense before as a cheaper option but now it's good enough to be your sole device. You don't see companies do this very often, offering something inexpensive which could eat shares of their other offerings but thank you Amazon, the dot is now very good and worth owning. For the record, the Echo sounds much better (like, way better) but for a lot of buyers, the difference would be negligible.

Title: Speaker blew in one day
Body: Never played music out of the device, it is linked to a bluetooth speaker.  After one day of simple questions and answers the speaker is blown.  Received device as part of a promotion, wanting to get a home assistant/smart speaker I thought I'd give this a try.  Needless to say I'll be purchasing a Google Home or Apple Home Pod.  Had much better expectations from Amazon - very disappointed.

Title: Great novelty, but can be difficult to set up.
Body: I finally decided to get on the home assistant bandwagon and got the echo dot. Mainly to interface with my home media center and TV. However, the DirecTV skill is worthless. Nobody gets it to work most of the time. If you want it to control your media center, you must pay for another service to interface with it. It will play Spotify songs on demand, but only if you have a Premium Spotify account. It controls DISH Network well I understand though. If you want it to control things in the house, the items must be attached to smart plugs or some home automation, and all of this requires setup and training. So if you think you're going to plug it in and start telling it to do everything you want it to, you may be in for a disappointment. I mainly use it for the time, temperature, news, audio books, reminders, timers and a few other things. I

Title: On again off again
Body: It's great when it is working. But that is the problem, it doesn't work all of the time. There are some days when the Dot 3 tells me that "it doesn't understand". I unplug it and it may come back "on-line"  and then there are days when unplugging it does nothing and it just turns red and "hhhuummmms" at me.I never have any problems with my Echo Dot 2.

Title: Speaker is now good, great upgrade from 2nd Gen.
Body: This is a night and day upgrade for the Echo Dot (2nd Gen) for music.  The old Dot (2nd Gen)  was tinny and did not sound good for music, the new Dot (3rd Gen) is awesome.  It actually has some good bass and is totally listenable on it's own without needing to pair a Bluetooth speaker when listing to music.  You can still pair the new Dot if you want to, but it sounds so much better than the old one you probably don't need to in a small to medium room.  I really like the 3rd Gen Dot it looks beefier but is still nice and small.  It sounds as good if not better than a Google Home Mini (IMHO).  Great upgrade got a $5 credit for turning in my old 2nd Gen Dot plus a 15% discount on a new 3rd Gen Dot.  Totally worth the price, especially if you don't have an external Bluetooth speaker on your 2nd Gen Dot.  If you like to listen to music and don't have a BT speaker to pair your old Dot with this is a no brainer.  Highly Recommend.

Title: The Echo Dot Is So Much Fun!
Body: It's almost like having a roommate! I can ask Alexa what time it is, what the temperature is outside, what the weather forecast is for tomorrow, and then ask her to play music. Since I have a FireTV, I can ask Alexa to find a movie or show, and it appears on my TV screen!  She got to know my voice by asking me to repeat about 10 phrases. She's keeping track of my grocery list, and with the Alexa app on my phone, I don't have to write anything down - my grocery list shows up on my phone at the grocery store. I've had her remind me of things on my To-Do list, and set an alarm to wake me up.  I've enabled some of her skills so that I can get News Flashes, learn about geology and even Spanish. I was able to pair the Echo Dot with my BoomBot speaker so that I can walk around the house and even go outside and listen to as much music as I want. I can ask her to Pause the music so that I can ask her a question, and then have her continue to play the music that I was listening to - she picks up right where the song left off. I know there's a lot more to discover, and I'm having fun with it.  I would highly recommend the Echo Dot. It's an excellent addition to any home.

Title: 3rd gen is best Echo Dot so far
Body: well what can i say other then this Dot is similar to the other Generations, except the sound quality is much better.  I have google home / home mini and other Echo products.  I had a home mini in the kitchen because it had better sound, after i received the 3rd gen Dot I put it in the much used kitchen.  ( Wife and I like to listen to music when cooking).One of the other things to note my wife says the Echo (s) works better, she says that she almost never has to repeat herself.  She would complain that the Google doesn't hear her correctly and she would have to repeat herself.  I agree with her somewhat, the echo seems to allow for wider variations of phases / words / or voices  VS. Google home.

Title: GREAT Sound!!!!
Body: I ordered this on Friday afternoon and received it on sat before noon!!!! I absolutely LOVE it! This is the first Alexa I have had so have nothing to compare it to but the sound is great for a small device! Very clear. did fiddle with the bass a little but not hard to work at all. I had it setup in less than 10 minutes. I love it! The shopping list is soooo easy, just tell her what to put on it and open the list on your phone in the store and check things off. The timer is great too as you can hear it in other rooms. The music sounds wonderful too. Still have to check out the book and podcast reading. Love Alexa! Considering buying another for the bedroom so I can listen to the wonderful sleep sounds like rainforest and beach sounds. Also considering buying several for Christmas gifts.

Title: the third generation is mind blowing thank you Amazon  now you. Really Rock LOL !!!!
Body: If  don't have one yet you are missing out this third generation all new Echo Dot is unbelievable who would've thought you can't even compare The two from the  Power plug to the base in the speakers to the quality of sound the overall good looks n design I would have to give it a 10 hands-down one of the nicest changes from Amazon to the consumers still for a unbelievable low price what a deal.

Title: Great addition to my living room
Body: This recently arrived in the mail and already I've gotten great use out of it. Its shape and texture is nice and unobtrusive, sound quality is just fine for what I use it for, and Alexa has so many skills available (I'm trying a few out to see what I think).This is my first Echo/Alexa product. I was visiting some family recently (I think they have 2nd gen dots) and had the chance to ask Alexa a few things and play various music for me and I saw where this would come in handy in my regular life at home. I've hooked this up to my Pandora account and also asked it to play other sounds for me to leave on for my cat while out of the house.For those times where I just want to listen to music, this is so much more energy-efficient than turning on my TV and DVD player just to hear my favorite Pandora stations.

Title: Garbage!
Body: Alexa is an ass. Connecting this thing is so difficult and cannot connect to free WiFi or WiFi with a user name and password. Setup should be done with Bluetooth not WiFi this is crap!

Title: This gadget is so FUN
Body: We_e been considering slowly turning our house into a smart home.  The Echo Dot has put this on a faster track.  Why we haven_ gotten one of these sooner, I_l never know.The Echo recognizes voice commands (we are on a steep learning curve with Alexa_ skills, but we_e getting there), plays nice with the Fire TV, and the little speaker sounds really good.  Seriously, you need to get this!

Title: Doesn't work
Body: Mine doesn't do anything I ask it to do. Can't read half of my kindle books to me.

Title: kids love this.  Sound is excellent in my opinion after accounting for size
Body: It took me under 5 minutes to get this online though I still need to tinker extensively with integrating it I don't forsee this being an issue.  I would give it 5 stars but I have only had it for 24 and want more time first.  My first impressions :- it is solidly built as it is heavier in the hand than expected.- It's sound is very good for its size.- I have a 6 yr old 4 yr old and 2 yr old.  They were transfixed by the joke function which has been pretty hilarious to watch.- It does a surprisingly good job finding songs if you know the artist and song name though performance I find so far is significantly worse for song title alone.- I actually was trying to talk to it within 10 minutes of setting up.  It is very good at encouraging a conversational approach.  I do a lot of dictation and I struggle with dragon not understanding me as wel as I would like but alexa does well for single commands- a Con is the initial fun of conversation grinds to a halt after about the 2nd step of the conversation.  Alexa for me thus far really just does 1-2 step interactions and nothing more complex.- Overall very happy with purchase.  Very interesting gadget.  I think I will find legitimately useful applications in the next month or so for it even with a mostly "dumb" house currently

Title: Juice isn_ worth the squeeze
Body: I haven_ had this for a month and it doesn_ do what I need it to do when I need it to do it. I_e done 2 factory resets, now I_ being told that I have to do a third to make it work. I just want some music and to voice control lights. This hassle isn_ worth the reward. Maybe if you have a fully automated home it_ wotht the wand trouble but for me - it_ a buggy pain in the butt.

Title: Great sound, great AI, great product
Body: I don't know why I had held off getting this until now but I am so glad I did. I was so happy with this purchase that 2 weeks later I bought another one for my girlfriend so I wouldn't be without Alexa when I was at her house.Alexa is so smart and she understands me so well.The sound is amazing I don't understand the reviews saying that the sound isn't good. It's honestly as good or better than my Samsung 4K TV set.I would recommend this to anyone and plan to buy one for my Mom.

Title: Don't rely on it for anything important
Body: I'm forced to use the online Alexa app because I don't own any Apple or Android device and my Windows 10 PC doesn't have the app. I'll list just a few of the problems I've had:1) It often fails to understand what I say. 2) It often fails to respond to my voice at all, though it's only two or three feet away. It responds to dead silence just as often as to my voice commands. 3) Many commands are not executed. For example, it will not make adjustments to the audio equalizer; it will not give my daily briefing items; it will not play stations saved to my iHeart favorites. 4) There's no product support. I've sent a number of email requests to support and received no response. 5) I had a bunch of recurring reminders set up, and they worked for a couple of days. Suddenly they all vanished. These were important work-related reminders. Of course, there's no way to back them up or save them. So, they're simply gone. 6) The audio quality is poor and sounds muffled no matter what I do. Speech is sometimes unintelligible. 7) Volume is unstable. During some music it will constantly decrease and I have to keep turning it up. Then when an announcer comes on, it's loud enough to take the paint off the walls.If I'd paid significant money, I would be returning it. For 99 cents, I can't be bothered. Maybe they will improve it in the future, but for now it serves no purpose; there's nothing it can do reliably. So I put it back in the box and stored it away.

Title: Too Complicated for me.
Body: I was unable to fight my way thru the Alexa App and Echo Dot settings.  You need a lot of streamlining before this thing will become popular with your average user.  I was disappointed too that you can't easilly use your own music with it.

Title: Unable to access alexa app
Body: After following the instructions  to add the alexa app I received a message that there was a problem.  I tried again, and again.  Finally I was referred to a website called 'fix it'.  There I was  told by the 'techs'  that my Amazon account was in jeopardy and that I needed to buy a fire wall from them.  Then they wanted to sell me some kind of WiFi adapter even though we have WiFi.  Hundreds of dollars to activate a $50 item.
